snippet: The estimate called into question whether the United States would have the resources to act quickly to thwart the movement of such weapons.
abstract: Pentagon has told Obama administration that any military effort to seize Syria’s stockpiles of chemical weapons would require upward of 75,000 troops, amid increasing concern that militant group Hezbollah has set up small training camps close to some chemical weapons depots.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Elisabeth Bumiller and Michael R. Gordon contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The estimate called into question whether the United States would have the resources to act quickly to thwart the movement of such weapons.

headline.seo: 75,000 U.S. Troops May Be Needed to Grab Syria Chemical Arms
headline.main: Pentagon Says 75,000 Troops Might Be Needed to Seize Syria Chemical Arms
headline.print_headline: Pentagon Says 75,000 Troops Might Be Needed to Seize Syria Chemical Arms
